title: 114_hr5974
content: The Act may be cited as the "Coptic Churches Accountability Act". Congress finds that in August 2013, Islamist-led mobs burned and destroyed Christian properties in Egypt after the government led by the Muslim Brotherhood was removed. President Sisi ordered the army to rebuild the damaged churches, showing recognition of the Coptic community's role. President Sisi also made an appearance at a Coptic Christmas liturgy in January 2015 and addressed the sectarian violence in a speech at St. Mark's Cathedral in Cairo in January 2016. In January 2016, President Sisi apologized for the delay in renovating churches burned during the 2013 violence and promised restoration. The Egyptian military and private citizens have restored some damaged buildings, but 29 buildings still need restoration as of September 2016. Egypt passed a law in August 2016 imposing restrictions on church construction. In August 2016, Egypt passed a law imposing significant burdens on church construction, leading to sectarian violence targeting Christians. In El-`Our, Minya, villagers protested the building of a new church honoring Christians beheaded by Da'esh militants. Protestors armed with Molotov cocktails and bricks besieged the existing village church and set fire to a Christian-owned vehicle. The Coptic Christians in Egypt have faced sectarian violence, with protestors attacking churches and Christian-owned property. Reconciliation sessions led by government officials have been criticized for favoring the majority religious group. The Coptic Church is the largest Christian community in the Middle East, with a history in Egypt dating back over 2,000 years. The US plays a role in protecting religious minorities internationally through diplomatic efforts. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 emphasizes the importance of condemning violations of religious freedom and promoting this fundamental right. Religious freedom is crucial for democracy, individual liberty, and stability, and the United States prioritizes promoting this value in its interactions with other countries. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of State must provide a report on the progress of restoring Christian religious properties in Egypt after the 2013 sectarian violence, including discussions with Egyptian officials, implementation of church construction permits, and an assessment of Egyptian laws and policies. The Secretary of State must ensure that annual reports on human rights practices and international religious freedom for Egypt include information on the implementation of church construction permits and Egyptian laws regarding Christian churches. The annual reports on human rights practices and international religious freedom for Egypt must include a summary of information on Christian church properties damaged during sectarian violence in August 2013.
